results.title: Shadow Play [interactive]
results.brief_description: The discovery of fire not only banished the darkness and provided warmth to our ancestors, it also allowed them to shape their imagination by projecting shadows, which visitors can do at the entrance to The Story of the Moving Image.

constellations_primary.name: Shadow play
constellations_primary.description: Shadow play uses light and projection to tell stories – fundamentals that would evolve into cinematography. In the Wayang tradition, gunungan open and close performances and indicate scene changes and the puppets pass across the projection screen in a similar way to a wipe transition.

results.description:
The discovery of fire not only banished the darkness and provided warmth to our ancestors, it also allowed them to shape their imagination by projecting shadows.

Relive the origins of the moving image by casting your own shadow as it bends, towers and twists to craft imagined worlds, wonderous characters and incredible tales in this interactive experience that unites ancient storytelling techniques with modern technology.
description_for_label:
The discovery of fire not only banished the darkness and provided warmth to our ancestors, it also allowed them to shape their imagination by projecting shadows.

Relive the origins of the moving image by casting your own shadow as it bends, towers and twists to craft imagined worlds, wonderous characters and incredible tales in this interactive experience that unites ancient storytelling techniques with modern technology.

results.title: VCS1 and VCS3 Synthesiser, from Don Banks music studio
results.brief_description: The soundtrack to Doctor Who’s battles with the Daleks was made by the VCS3. This portable synthesiser was created in 1969 and was originally commissioned by Australian composer Don Banks who wanted an instrument that would let him work at home.

constellations_primary.name: The Suspense Constellation
constellations_primary.description: An exploration of music in suspense works.

results.title_for_label: VCS1 and VCS3 Synthesiser, from Don Banks music studio
results.description:
The soundtrack to Doctor Who’s battles with the Daleks was made by the VCS3. This portable synthesiser was created in 1969 by Tristram Cary, David Cockerell and Peter Zinovieff at London’s Electronic Music Studio. It was originally commissioned by Australian composer Don Banks who wanted an instrument that would let him work at home.

“Thank heaven for the age of miniaturisation because this was small enough for me to take to bed with headphones and start to explore a new world of sound.” – Don Banks
description_for_label:

results.title: Glass slide magic lantern
results.brief_description:
Glass slide projector as used by Department of Agriculture, Melbourne.
Lens can be compacted or extended, see attached images from ICS.
Modifications include addition of electricity and edision bulb.
1 Box containing 2 parts.

results.title: Bare
results.creator_credit: Wild Iris Productions, Liz Baulch, Amanda Roberts, Deborah Strutt and Elizabeth Taylor Sometimes
results.brief_description: The morning after the night before… Dee wakes up with a stranger in her bed, while her neighbour Paul is discovering new spice in an old relationship. But when inner city living finds them at closer quarters than they might expect, sensual surprises and unexpected desires are the order of the day. Keeping up with the Joneses was never this much fun!

results.title: Grand Théâtre Fantasmagorique shadow play set
results.brief_description: Shadow play sets used decorative paper puppets to cast short fables and fairytales. Popular in China for over 2000 years, they were later merged with other innovations, like magic lanterns, to project ghoulish phantasmagoria shows.
results.description:
Shadow puppetry has been popular in China for more than 2,000 years. Invented to entertain Emperor Wu of the Han dynasty, shadow plays were transported to Europe by travellers in the mid-18th century. There they were known as ombres chinoises (Chinese shadows) and were adapted to tell European stories. Puppeteer François Dominique Séraphin made them popular when he presented them in Paris in 1776, and by 1781 he was dazzling the court at the Palace of Versailles. Even Marie Antoinette admired his work.

Shadow play sets like this one used decorative paper puppets to cast short fables and fairytales. Later they were merged with other innovations, like magic lanterns, to project ghoulish phantasmagoria shows.
description_for_label:

Puppeteer François Dominique Séraphin made them popular when he presented them in Paris in 1776, and by 1781 he was dazzling the court at the Palace of Versailles. Even Marie Antoinette admired his work.

Shadow play sets like this one used decorative paper puppets to cast short fables and fairytales. Later they were merged with other innovations, like magic lanterns, to project ghoulish phantasmagoria shows.

results.title: Star wars
results.creator_credit: George Lucas, Gary Kurtz, Lucasfilm, Ltd. and Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation
results.brief_description: A Long time ago in a galaxy far far away, George Lucas’s space adventure captured the hearts and imaginations of film lovers of all ages from the moment these words scrolled across the screen. The Empire’s evil Death Star must be destroyed. The heroes, Luke Skywalker, Princess Leia, Han Solo and a pair of droids named R2-D2 and C-3PO, as part of the Rebel Alliance, must pit their strength against the might of the Empire and the evil Jedi, Darth Vader. With the help of an old Jedi Knight, Obi-Wan Kenobi, they battle the forces of darkness and triumph. The special effects and famous “Star wars” theme music has ensured that this film takes its place in cinema history. Includes a ten minute interview between George Lucas and Leonard Maltin.

constellations_other.name: The Wilhelm scream, easters eggs and open world games
constellations_other.description: This Constellation tracks how an on-set in-joke became one of the first cinematic easter eggs. It was made by Swinburne Cinema and Screen Studies students Harrison Buikstra and Jasper Caverly.

results.title: The Body Malleable
results.material_description: video, interactive software, mixed media, colour and sound
results.brief_description: The Body Malleable is an intimate interactive work where a custom built ‘gromit’ is physically engaged with by the viewer to create a display combining digital animation and synchronised audio in the installation space. The custom interface, placed on a desk for one viewer to interact with at a time, is internally configured with a 100 key keyboard broken up and reassembled within the spherical space. Darkness within the pod, the viewer is asked to insert their finger into a small opening to probe the key board lining. The keys pressed act as switches to key events programmed into Director and thus set off a series of audio-visual responses via surround sound and a single circular screen projection to create an intimate experiential space determined by the audiences interaction.
